solutions.content:
Pass current maximum parent value via argument and count the sum of good nodes recursively. We use ternary conditional expression (X if COND else Y) to make a one-liner. Also use the fact that boolean value is implicitly cast to 1 if True and 0 if False.
```
def goodNodes(self, root: TreeNode, curMax: int = -10000) -> int:
    return self.goodNodes(root.left, max(root.val, curMax)) + self.goodNodes(root.right, max(root.val, curMax)) + (root.val >= curMax) if root else 0
```

```

It's a bit strange to me how this question, which is just traversing a tree, is marked medium. A question like [subtree of another tree](https://leetcode.com/problems/subtree-of-another-tree/) is marked easy and that seems objectively more complex, you couldn't do that question without the capability to do this one.
i can do it in my head but its not efficience tho
exactly sub tree of another tree is bit complexed than this \n
Try to think in such a way: is it simple just for you or for all people?

# Hints + Github Gist Solution
As we traverse the paths, the current node can be one of three things:

1. Less than a node in the current path
2. Equal to a node in the current path
3. Greater than a node in the current path

In the first case, we ignore this node from our result.

In cases two and three we need to update the "greatest" node in the current path so far and pass this along to the rest of our recursive calls. You can think of it like: "nodes further down the tree have a harder time being included in the result since there are more nodes in front of them to drive up the minimum value to be included"

Then just setup the correct base case and recursive calls and you are done. 

My recursive solution used:
- Two parameters: current_node and current_min_of_path
- Two new recursive calls spawned at each valid node
- Base case when a node is null. Consider carefully what value we want to return in this case...

## Still stuck?
[Solution](https://gist.github.com/sim1029/696ad81cd02f7627d96a9b9fe991e73f)
Why is this question marked as medium? Shouldn\u2019t it be easy? It\'s just a simple dfs/bfs with little extra logic. Or am I missing something?

yes i don\'t know why it\'s marked as  medium the only thing here is just do simple dfs by having the parent as maximum of the path so far but still it could be difficult for beginners maybe but yeah it should be marked as easy
Agree
Try to think in such a way: is it simple just for you or for all people?

agree
Don\'t see the world only from your perspective.
I\'m having trouble understanding the question.\nI thought it said, the root node\'s value is the max and any children nodes with a value greater than the root node should be counted as bad.

It must be because you don\'t need to explicitly pass the count variable in countNodes function as it will change its value inside the function only but when you return it inside goodNodes function you are getting gloabal value of count which is still 0.

Here in this input at index 1 we have null as input.

How we could have 10 as Left Child and 8 as Right Child for null 

Can any one tell me the tree structure for this input
Could you please share the test case?
why is [-1,5,-2,4,4,2,-2,null,null,-4,null,-2,3,null,-2,0,null,-1,null,-3,null,-4,-3,3,null,null,null,null,null,null,null,3,-3]\na valid test case?? it doesn\'t seem to make a binary tree?
Bruh, they say each node\'s value is between -10^4 and 10^4 but -10^4 = (-10)^4 = 1000 = 10^4
Just try to remember max in the path you dont have to worry about other numbers.
Should be marked as Easy.

# Hints + Github Gist Solution
As we traverse the paths, the current node can be one of three things:

1. Less than a node in the current path
2. Equal to a node in the current path
3. Greater than a node in the current path

In the first case, we ignore this node from our result.

In cases two and three we need to update the "greatest" node in the current path so far and pass this along to the rest of our recursive calls. You can think of it like: "nodes further down the tree have a harder time being included in the result since there are more nodes in front of them to drive up the minimum value to be included"

Then just setup the correct base case and recursive calls and you are done. 

My recursive solution used:
- Two parameters: current_node and current_min_of_path
- Two new recursive calls spawned at each valid node
- Base case when a node is null. Consider carefully what value we want to return in this case...

title: Sentence Similarity III
question_content:
A sentence is a list of words that are separated by a single space with no leading or trailing spaces. For example, "Hello World", "HELLO", "hello world hello world" are all sentences. Words consist of only uppercase and lowercase English letters.

Two sentences sentence1 and sentence2 are similar if it is possible to insert an arbitrary sentence (possibly empty) inside one of these sentences such that the two sentences become equal. For example, sentence1 = "Hello my name is Jane" and sentence2 = "Hello Jane" can be made equal by inserting "my name is" between "Hello" and "Jane" in sentence2.

Given two sentences sentence1 and sentence2, return true if sentence1 and sentence2 are similar. Otherwise, return false.

 

Example 1:

Input: sentence1 = "My name is Haley", sentence2 = "My Haley"
Output: true
Explanation: sentence2 can be turned to sentence1 by inserting "name is" between "My" and "Haley".

Example 2:

Input: sentence1 = "of", sentence2 = "A lot of words"
Output: false
Explanation: No single sentence can be inserted inside one of the sentences to make it equal to the other.

Example 3:

Input: sentence1 = "Eating right now", sentence2 = "Eating"
Output: true
Explanation: sentence2 can be turned to sentence1 by inserting "right now" at the end of the sentence.

 

Constraints:

  • 1 <= sentence1.length, sentence2.length <= 100
  • sentence1 and sentence2 consist of lowercase and uppercase English letters and spaces.
  • The words in sentence1 and sentence2 are separated by a single space.

solutions.content:
assmue ```s1``` is the shorter string
```len1, len2``` are the maximum length of substrings starting from each end of ```s2``` and equal to part of ```s1```.
```s1``` and ```s2``` is similar only when ```len1 + len2 >= len(s1)```

Therefore we just use a pointer start from ```index = 0```, move pointer rightward until ```s1[index] != s2[index]```, this is the substring on left end of s2 which equals to left part of s1.
Then start from ```index = n - 1```, decrease the index until ```s1[index] != s2[index]```, this is the substing on the right end of s2. 

![image](https://assets.leetcode.com/users/images/e89089e6-22f1-4cf7-8966-dd62c40d1fe2_1617467501.322186.png)



```
def areSentencesSimilar(s1, s2):
    s1, s2 = s1.split(), s2.split()
    if len(s1) > len(s2):
        s1, s2 = s2, s1
    n, i, j = len(s1), 0, 1
    while i < n and s1[i] == s2[i]:
        i += 1
    while j < n + 1 and s1[-j] == s2[-j]:
        j += 1
    return i + j > n
```

solutions.content:
```
class Solution:
    def areSentencesSimilar(self, sentence1: str, sentence2: str) -> bool:
        words1, words2 = sentence1.split(), sentence2.split()
        n1, n2 = len(words1), len(words2)
        if n1 == n2:  return sentence1 == sentence2    # the two strings must be identical if their lengths are the same
        if words1[0] != words2[0] and words1[-1] != words2[-1]:  return False
        i = j = 0
        flag = False
        while i < n1 and j < n2:
            if words1[i] != words2[j]:
                if flag:  return False    # a mismatch had already been found before
                flag = True
                if n1 < n2:  
                    while j < n2 and words2[j] != words1[i]:  j += 1
                    if j == n2:  return False 
                else:
                    while i < n1 and words1[i] != words2[j]:  i += 1
                    if i == n1:  return False
            i += 1
            j += 1
        return True if (not flag or i == n1 and j == n2) else False
```

solutions.content:
```
class Solution:
    def areSentencesSimilar(self, sentence1: str, sentence2: str) -> bool:
        s1 = sentence1.split()
        s2 = sentence2.split()
        # let s1 be the shorter sequence
        if len(s1) > len(s2):
            s1,s2 = s2,s1
        # find the first index where they differ
        i = 0
        while i < len(s1):
            if s1[i] != s2[i]:
                break
            i += 1
        # check if the trailing part of s1 matches the end of s2
        return s1[i:] == s2[len(s2) - (len(s1) - i):]
```

class Solution:
    def areSentencesSimilar(self, sentence1: str, sentence2: str) -> bool:
        arr1=sentence1.split(' ')
        arr2=sentence2.split(' ')
        while arr1 and arr2 and arr1[-1]==arr2[-1]:
            arr1.pop()
            arr2.pop()
        arr1.reverse()
        arr2.reverse()
        while arr1 and arr2 and arr1[-1]==arr2[-1]:
            arr1.pop()
            arr2.pop()
        return not arr1 or not arr2
```

```
class Solution:
    def areSentencesSimilar(self, sentence1: str, sentence2: str) -> bool:
        s1 = deque(sentence1.split(' '))
        s2 = deque(sentence2.split(' '))
        
        while s1 and s2 and s1[0] == s2[0]:
            s1.popleft()
            s2.popleft()
        
        while s1 and s2 and s1[-1] == s2[-1]:
            s1.pop()
            s2.pop()
        
        return len(s1)==0 or len(s2) == 0
        
        
```

class Solution(object):
    def areSentencesSimilar(self, sa, sb):
        tempa=sa
        tempb=sb
        if len(sa)>len(sb):
            sa=tempb
            sb=tempa
            
        lst1=sa.split()
        lst2=sb.split()
        
        l=0
        
        while l<len(lst1) and lst1[l]==lst2[l]:
            l=l+1
            
        if l==len(lst1):
            return True
        
        ra=len(lst1)-1
        rb=len(lst2)-1
        
        while ra>=0 and lst1[ra]==lst2[rb]:
            ra=ra-1
            rb=rb-1
            
        if l>ra:
            return True
        return False
```

solutions.content:
# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->
Only single sentence can be inserted so only three positions possible

#### Insert Left
Ex: s1 = "now", s2 = "Eating right now"

__"Eating right"__ + "now == "Eating right now"


#### Insert Right
Ex: s1 = "Eating", s2 = "Eating right now"

"Eating" + __"right now"__ == "Eating right now"

#### Insert Middle
Ex: s1 = "Eating now", s2 = "Eating right now"

"Eating" + __"right"__ + "now" == "Eating right now"

# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->
Let smaller of sentence be sentence1
Take a pointer i = 0

Move the pointer till s1[i] == s2[i] (covering the left part)

Then skip the pointer by n2 - n1 in s2 distance to skip different words (check insert left example) then again

Move the pointer till s1[i] == s2[n2 - n1 + i] (covering the right part)

If i == len(s1) means we covered all the words and we can insert a sentence to make s1 == s2

# Complexity
- Time complexity: O(S1 + S2) 
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->


- Space complexity: O(S1 + S2)
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

# Code
```
class Solution:
    def areSentencesSimilar(self, sentence1: str, sentence2: str) -> bool:
        l1 = sentence1.split()
        l2 = sentence2.split()
        n1 = len(l1)
        n2 = len(l2)
        if n1 > n2:
            n1, n2 = n2, n1
            l1, l2 = l2[:], l1[:]

        i = 0
        while i < n1 and l1[i] == l2[i]:
            i += 1
        while i < n1 and l1[i] == l2[n2 - n1 + i]:
            i += 1

        return i == n1

```

        if n1 > n2:
            n1, n2 = n2, n1

        i = 0
        while i < n1 and l1[i] == l2[i]:
            i += 1
        while i < n1 and l1[i] == l2[n2 - n1 + i]:
            i += 1

        return i == n1

```

solutions.content:
# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->

# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->

# Complexity
- Time complexity: n * m
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->
In this code we have splited the given string to array. 
so it will take less time than n * m
Where 
n -> len(str1)
m -> len(str2)

- Space complexity: n * m
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->
We have used memoization which is 2d. so it consumes n * m.
Where 
n -> len(str1)
m -> len(str2)

# Code
```
class Solution:
    def areSentencesSimilar(self, sentence1: str, sentence2: str) -> bool:
        str1 = sentence1.split()
        str2 = sentence2.split()
        dp = {}
        def solve(i, j, c, flag):
            if j == len(str2):
                return c <= 1
            if i >= len(str1):
                return False
            if (i, j, c) in dp:
                return dp[(i, j, c)]
            ans = False
            if str2[j] == str1[i]:
                #ans |= solve(i+1, j, c, flag)
                ans |= solve(i+1, j+1, c, False)
            if flag:
                ans |= solve(i+1, j, c, flag)
            ans |= solve(i+1, j, c+1, True)
            dp[(i, j, c)] = ans
            return ans
        st = (str1[0] == str2[0]) or (str1[-1] == str2[-1])
        opt =  solve(0, 0, 0, False) and st
        dp = {}
        str1, str2 = str2, str1
        return (solve(0, 0, 0, False) or opt) and st
```

<!-- # Intuition -->
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->

# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->
- functional
- `assert issubclass(bool, int)`

# Complexity
- Time complexity: $$O(min(n1, n2))$$
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

- Space complexity: $$O(n1+n2)$$
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

# Code
```
class Solution:
    def areSentencesSimilar(self, sentence1: str, sentence2: str) -> bool:
        prefix = lambda xs, ys: sum(takewhile(bool, map(eq, xs, ys)))
        W1, W2 = map(str.split, (sentence1, sentence2))
        return prefix(W1, W2) + prefix(reversed(W1), reversed(W2)) >= min(len(W1), len(W2))
```

class Solution:
    def areSentencesSimilar(self, sentence1: str, sentence2: str) -> bool:
        if sentence1==sentence2: return True

        longer = sentence1 if len(sentence1) >= len(sentence2) else sentence2
        shorter = sentence1 if len(sentence1) < len(sentence2) else sentence2
        
        s1Arr = longer.split(" ")
        N = len(s1Arr)
        s2Arr = shorter.split(" ")

        check1 = [False] * len(s1Arr)
        check2 = [False] * len(s2Arr)

        i = 0     
        j = 0

        # Forward check
        while i<len(s1Arr) and j<len(s2Arr):
            if s1Arr[i] == s2Arr[j]:
                check1[i]=True
                check2[j]=True
                i+=1
                j+=1
            else:
                i+=1
        
        for e in check2:
            if e==False: return False

        cnt = 0
        prev = True
        for i in range(len(check1)):
            if check1[i] == False:
                if prev == True:
                    cnt += 1
            prev = check1[i]

        if cnt == 1: return True

        check1 = [False] * len(s1Arr)
        check2 = [False] * len(s2Arr)

        i = len(s1Arr)-1
        j = len(s2Arr)-1

        # Backward check
        while i>=0 and j>=0:
            print(i, j)
            if s1Arr[i] == s2Arr[j]:
                check1[i]=True
                check2[j]=True
                i-=1
                j-=1
            else:
                i-=1

        cnt = 0
        prev = True
        for i in range(len(check1)):
            if check1[i] == False:
                if prev == True:
                    cnt += 1
            prev = check1[i]

        if cnt == 1: return True

        return False


        
        
        
```

solutions.content:
# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->
Just track the count of words matched from starting and ending of the bigger sentence.
# Complexity
- Time complexity: O(n)
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->


# Code
```
class Solution(object):
    def areSentencesSimilar(self, s1, s2):
        # let word1 is smaller sentence and word2 is larger
        word1, word2 = s1.split(" "), s2.split(" ")
        s, l = len(word1), len(word2)
        if s>l:
            word1, word2 = word2, word1
            s,l = l,s
        

        i=0
        # number of words match from starting
        while i < s and word1[i]==word2[i]:
            i += 1
        # number of words match from ending
        while i < s and word1[i]==word2[l-s+i]:
            i += 1
        # if the words matched is equal to smaller sentence return True
        return i==s
    
```

class Solution(object):
    def areSentencesSimilar(self, s1, s2):
        # let word1 is smaller sentence and word2 is larger
        word1, word2 = s1.split(" "), s2.split(" ")
        s, l = len(word1), len(word2)
        if s>l:
            word1, word2 = word2, word1
            s,l = l,s
        

        i=0
        # number of words match from starting
        while i < s and word1[i]==word2[i]:
            i += 1
        # number of words match from ending
        while i < s and word1[i]==word2[l-s+i]:
            i += 1
        # if the words matched is equal to smaller sentence return True
        return i==s
    
```

solutions.content:
# Code
```
class Solution:
    def areSentencesSimilar(self, sentence1: str, sentence2: str) -> bool:
        s1 = sentence1.split()
        s2 = sentence2.split()
        n1, n2 = len(s1), len(s2)
        if n1 == n2: return s1 == s2
        if n1 > n2:
            s1, s2 = s2, s1
            n1, n2 = n2, n1
        i, j = 0, 1
        while i < n1 and s1[i] == s2[i]: i += 1
        while j <= n1 and s1[n1-j] == s2[n2-j]: j += 1
        return i + j - 1 >= n1 
```

class Solution:

        s1 = sentence1.split()
        s2 = sentence2.split()
        n1, n2 = len(s1), len(s2)
        if n1 == n2: return s1 == s2
        if n1 > n2:
            s1, s2 = s2, s1
            n1, n2 = n2, n1
        i, j = 0, 1
        while i < n1 and s1[i] == s2[i]: i += 1
        while j <= n1 and s1[n1-j] == s2[n2-j]: j += 1
        return i + j - 1 >= n1

solutions.content:
# Intuition


# Approach
Split the string by space 
Always compare from the shortest splited result
Find the first different index 
Substract the shortest array from index
Substract the longest array from the approate index
compare two substracted array (as string)



# Complexity
- Time complexity:
 $$O(n)$$ n = len(shortest arr after split)

- Space complexity:
 $$O(n)$$

# Code
```
class Solution:
    def areSentencesSimilar(self, sentence1: str, sentence2: str) -> bool:
        s2 = sentence2.split(' ')
        s1 = sentence1.split(' ')
        
        def compare(s1,s2):
            idx = 0
            for i in range(len(s2)):
                if s2[i] == s1[i]:
                    idx+=1
                else:
                    break
         
            left = s2[idx:]
            itemTake = len(s2)-idx
            right = s1[len(s1)-itemTake:]
            return ' '.join(left) == ' '.join(right)

            ## alternative way to save memory
            ## for i in range(idx, len(s2)):
            ##      if s2[i] != s1[len(s1)-len(s2)+i]:
            ##          return False
            ##      return True
            

        if len(s1) > len(s2):
            return compare(s1,s2)
        else:
            return compare(s2,s1)
    
```

wow this looked easy when reading the question , edgecases is where it got kind of tricky.
Same here. Seems easy, but had to iterate a few times before fixed all edgecases
Yeeeah, this task is exactly about edgecases

The acceptance rate concerned me at first, but I didn\'t find the "edge cases" to be problematic with a two-pointers approach (well, technically 3 pointers). Tokenize both strings into word tokens, set a single left pointer to the start of both strings and two right pointers, one each for the right side of each string. Iterate first from left while tokens of both strings match, break when condition fails. Do the same from the right side of both strings. Afterward, if the left pointer equals at least one of the right pointers, the sentences are similar.
Feels easy only until you discover edge cases

second condition ::->
2- check if s1[-1] == s2[-1]:
         pop (s1[-1] and s2[-1])
